children.subject: If you go to the academics tab of calcentral and look at the box for Fall 2017, you'll see a small link for book list. If you click it you'll see all the books for your classes in the Fall
With the usual caveat that those lists aren't necessarily accurate et cetera.
I don't know the answer to your question, but how do you know which textbook we need? The class doesn't have a Piazza or a website yet. I'm in the class too and was wondering :P

history.content: If you give the specific books, you would get a more specific answer- I will guess what they are.  I will say for the circuit portion of the class, if the textbook is Sedra/Smith (textbook when I took 105), it is not worth it, since it provides little intuition (for circuits, intuition is critical; go to lecture or office hours & practice to gain it).  The only circuit textbooks worth buying (at this level) are Grey, Hurst, Lewis, Meyer, or Razavi's analog CMOS textbook (since they will be used in 140 and later classes, and I have found them to be useful references outside of school etc).  For device physics, 105 doesn't go in depth enough to warrant buying a textbook: take 130 for that.  Any device-physics related questions can be (more than) answered in Prof. Chenming Hu's textbook given by Berkeley free here: https://people.eecs.berkeley.edu/~hu/Book-Chapters-and-Lecture-Slides-download.html.

Just wondering if anyone has experience with this. Is the book useful/helpful to have? I generally prefer books in physical format rather than PDFs, but only if they're important to the class.

Thanks!
history.subject: How Useful Is the EE105 Textbook?
